Award.AwardTitle: Modelling the Transport Revolution and the Industrial Revolution in England

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
There have been significant improvements in transportation infrastructure and technology over the last three hundred years. Our ancestors in the late 1800s did not have air-travel, internal combustion engines, and the inter-oceanic canals that people enjoy today. Transportation was even more difficult in the early 1700s because of poorly made roads, a lack of inland waterways, and the absence of steam power. How significant were these transport improvements to economic development over the last three hundred years?

It was in the 1700s that modern economic growth began with the Industrial Revolution in England. Changes in technology, like the advent of the steam engine, and the growth of manufacturing employment in cities allowed wages to begin their slow increase that continues to this day. Improvements to England's transport infrastructure and technology are possibly crucial factors underlying the Industrial Revolution. There was an expansion in river navigation and road infrastructure in the mid-1700s and by the early 1800s a canal network was created. The application of steam power in the 1830s further revolutionized transport leading to steam ships and railways.

The relationship between transportation improvements and the Industrial Revolution is much discussed by economists studying history and economic growth but there is no consensus on the magnitudes and the mechanisms of change. The importance of transport change goes beyond historical studies. It is well known that highly productive cities and regions can co-exist with less productive ones. Why is this so? Why does economic development not happen everywhere even when institutions are similar? One theory states that differences in the financial and time cost of reaching markets causes differences in development. History offers a unique context to study such theories because researchers can examine large-scale changes in infrastructure and communications technology.

This project makes use of advances in Geographical Information Systems (GIS) software to examine how transport improvements influenced the Industrial Revolution in England. Using GIS, it is now possible to precisely model the transport cost and travel time between any two locations provided there are digital maps of the transport network. The project will build on existing GIS maps of waterways and railways compiled by the Cambridge Group for the History of Population and Social Structure in the U.K. and it will create new GIS maps for turnpike roads, pre-turnpike roads, and ports. The maps will be dynamic displaying the transport network (road, water, or rail) at all points in time, say 1700, 1750, or 1850.

The dynamic GIS maps will be used to estimate shipping costs and travel times between all English cities in every year from 1700 to 1870. Shipping costs and travel times will be utilized to estimate the rate of productivity growth across the transport sector including the cost savings associated with the spread of good roads, canals and railways. The project will also estimate the "social saving" from transport innovations. The social saving of canals, for example, is measured by the added cost of shipping goods by road instead of by canal. This project will be the first to estimate the social saving using more precise measures of transport costs and traffic flows between cities. Moreover, it will assess each city's cost of accessing markets and study the effect on its wages and adoption of technologies, like the steam engine.

The research conducted under this grant -- which is jointly funded by the Economics Program and the Geography and Spatial Sciences -- is complementing theoretical and empirical work focusing on the links between market access and economic development in more recent time periods. The GIS maps of transport networks will be made available to the public and will constitute a valuable set of resources for diverse scholarly and educational purposes. Lastly, there is a potential impact on policy-making. If it is established that market access influences technology adoption then policy interventions related to transport may be able to accelerate productivity or change its spatial distribution.

POR.DRECONTENT:
It is well known that highly productive cities and regions can co-exist with less productive ones. Why is this so? Why does economic development not happen everywhere even when institutions are similar? One theory states that differences in market access cause differences in development. In this view transport plays a key role and can change the development path of cities and regions. History offers a unique context to study such theories because researchers can examine large-scale changes in infrastructure and communications technology. England’s economy was the first to achieve modern rates of economic growth during the industrial revolution. Coincident with these developments England’s transport infrastructure was transformed by improvements to rivers and roads and by the creation of a canal and rail network. How was the transport revolution related to the industrial revolution? This project provides a new quantitative foundation to answer this question.

This project uses advances in Geographical Information Systems (GIS) software. The project builds on existing GIS data for waterway and railway networks compiled by the Cambridge Group for the History of Population and Social Structure (CAMPOP) in the U.K. With these collaborators, the PI Bogart aimed to create new GIS data on transport and economic outcomes. The most notable from the perspective of this grant is the completion of a dynamic GIS of turnpike roads from 1663 to 1896. Turnpike roads are significant because they represented the main road network in England and Wales prior to the arrival of railways and they formed the largest toll road network in history.

The PI Bogart has worked with colleagues at CAMPOP to produce GIS data for the turnpike network, including roads present in 1700. Other GIS data was created using support from the NSF and in cooperation with CAMPOP. These include (1) a locations of sea ports, (2) locations of market towns in 1670, (3) locations of parliamentary enclosures, and (4) locations of steam engines installed before 1800.

The GIS maps of transport networks will be made available to the public and will constitute a valuable set of resources for scholarly and educational purposes. Maps are a key tool in our increasingly visual society. The public can see how transportation and economic activity change across space and time. Videos illustrating the evolution of networks are available and a historical travel journey planner tool is being developed. A full description of the data is available at the PI Bogart’s webpage http://www.socsci.uci.edu/~dbogart/index.htm

The GIS network data are being used to advance several research goals. The first is to estimate transport costs and travel times between all English towns in every year from 1700 to 1830. The PI Bogart along with collaborators at CAMPOP have built a multi-modal transport model to estimate these costs. The estimates show substantial reductions in the level of transport costs and its variability across space. The estimates are significant because no study has previously tried to analyze all transport improvements. We think this will inspire other researchers to study changes in the transport system, not individual components, like roads or canals.  

Recently the economics profession has focused much attention on the relationship between local economic growth and access to markets. The PI Bogart and colleagues are the first to extend the approach to the era before 1850. We find evidence shows that a location’s change in market access is strongly correlated with its population growth from 1680 to 1830. Our estimated relationship is similar to studies on the late 20th century like China and India. We think this is exciting because our estimates contribute to a growing consensus on the parametric relationship between market access and growth.

We also have evidence that access to transport infrastructure like turnpike roads, canals, ports, and railways significantly affected local population and employment density. We compare our estimates with other studies. We find that access to railways in the U.K. in the 19th century had a smaller effect than access to highways in the 20th century United States. Within the U.K. our estimates suggest that the effects of proximity to more advanced transport infrastructure, like railways and steamships, are larger than for less advanced transport, like turnpike roads. While this makes sense, ours is the first study to do so for the pre-1850 period.

Finally, there is little research in economics linking transport infrastructure and technology adoption, especially for a ‘macro-innovations.’ Through this grant, we provide the first estimates of the relationship between steam engine adoption and distance to turnpikes and inland waterways. There is a broader policy implication, because our research shows how transport improvements can contribute to technologies which transform the entire economy.
